title: Reptiles Alive! and Dead! at The Field Museum
author: Unknown
summary: The Field Museum in Chicago is featuring two kinds of reptile exhibits: the 'Reptiles Alive!' exhibit, open until April 5, 2026, featuring 20 live species, and 'Reptiles Dead!', represented by the museum's vast collection of 11 million embalmed specimens. These 'pickled creatures' are crucial for scientific research, allowing for the discovery of new species and the study of minute anatomical variations.

sections.heading: Reptiles Alive!
sections.content: The Field Museum in Chicago has a new exhibit; Reptiles Alive! Open until April 5, 2026, this exhibit is open to all ages, and features “20 live reptiles, including a baby alligator, spitting cobra, legless lizard, and emerald tree boa”.

sections.heading: Reptiles Dead!
sections.content: But not only does the Field Museum have “Reptiles Alive!” it also has “Reptiles Dead!” as the Field Museum features almost 11 million embalmed specimens, many of these being unique and endangered reptiles.

sections.heading: The Value of Pickled Creatures
sections.content: Pickled creatures are a unique way to study reptiles. Entirely new species have been discovered from reptiles sitting in jars post-mortem. From being able to get up close and count the exact number of scales, or how each bone placement is affected by a certain movement, scientists can discover distinct variations between species. Especially when specific mutations are considered outliers, being able to draw on dozens of other similar specimens allow scientists to make these new distinctions.

sections.heading: The Preservation Process
sections.content: Reptiles are picked in three simple steps. First, they are tagged, so that researchers both in the present and future can identify the species, where it originated, and where to find it in the vast collection of preserved animals. Then, they are injected with carcinogens, which make the animal tissue stiff and rubbery. Lastly, they are submerged in ethanol to complete the preservation process.

sections.heading: Komodo Dragons in the Collection
sections.content: The Field Museum has two komodo dragons preserved this way, submerged in large alcohol tubs, as both around six feet long.

image.caption: A preserved reptile specimen in the Field Museum collection.

title: ReptileMap 2025: Empowering Youth with Technology
author: ReptileMap Summit Committee
summary: The Annual ReptileMap Summit, held virtually this year, focuses on 'Empowering Youth with Technology to Advocate for Citizen Science.' The event brings together experts and students to discuss how digital tools, mapping, and AI are being used to drive environmental impact, featuring speakers like the founder of SightTrack Map and ASU's Dr. Anthony Barley.

sections.heading: Invitation to the Annual ReptileMap Summit
sections.content:
We’re excited to invite you to the Annual ReptileMap Summit, happening this Sunday, October 26th, from 1:30–4:00 p.m. ET / 10:30 a.m.–1:00 p.m. PT on Zoom.

This year’s theme is: **Empowering Youth with Technology to Advocate for Citizen Science**

This virtual event will bring together educators, researchers, tech innovators, and passionate students to explore how emerging tools, from digital mapping to AI, are enabling youth to drive meaningful environmental impact.

image.caption: ReptileMap Summit: Empowering Youth with Technology

sections.heading: Summit Program Highlights
sections.content:
• Opening Remarks
  • Guest Speaker 1: Founder of SightTrack Map – on community mapping and youth engagement
  • Panel Discussion: Youth voices and tech-driven advocacy in conservation
  • Guest Speaker 2: Dr. Anthony Barley
  • Workshop: "Vibe Coding with AI to Promote Citizen Science" led by Mark Hoel

sections.heading: About Guest Speaker Dr. Anthony Barley
sections.content: Dr. Anthony Barley is an Assistant Professor in the School of Mathematical and Natural Sciences at Arizona State University. Dr. Barley grew up in California and received his Bachelor of Science degree in Biological Science from California State University, Sacramento. He received a Ph.D. in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology from the University of Kansas in 2014. After graduating, he went on to do postdoctoral research at the University of Hawaii where he was awarded a postdoctoral fellowship from the Arnold and Mabel Beckman Foundation. He also worked as an Assistant Project Scientist at the University of California, Davis, before joining the faculty at ASU in 2022. Dr. Barley studies the evolution and conservation of reptiles and amphibians in the Southwestern U.S, Southeast Asia, and Mexico.

sections.heading: What is this talk about?

title: Nature in Winter
The Winter Show at The Wurlitzer
author: Jacob Shi
summary: 908 Niagara Falls Boulevard, North Tonawanda, NY 14120, United States

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.content: Get ready for a slithery and scaly extravaganza at the The Winter Show at The Wurlitzer brought to you by WNY Reptiles!

image.caption: WNY reptiles presents Winter at the Wurlitzer

sections.heading: What is this talk about?
sections.content: Join us for a day filled with fascinating reptiles, educational exhibits, and interactive experiences. Whether you’re a seasoned reptile enthusiast, oddities collector, plant aficionado, or just curious about these amazing creatures, this event is perfect for all ages.

sections.heading: What will I learn?
sections.content: Come meet a variety of reptiles up close, learn about their habitats, and even have the chance to handle some of them! Check out our carnivorous plant displays, maybe even take one home! Do you like the unusual? Visit our oddities vendors for preserved specimens, taxidermy, mounts and more! Don’t miss out on this unique opportunity to appreciate the beauty and diversity of reptiles while exploring the historic Wurlitzer building.

sections.heading: Mark your calendars
sections.content: Mark your calendars and join us for a day of fun and learning at the The Winter Show at The Wurlitzer!

sections.heading: What is this talk about?
sections.content: Bring world-class nature education into your living room with a Zoo-Zoom experience! Join other alumni kids from around the world to learn about an awesome assortment of cool creatures with an Animal Educator from Little Ray’s Nature Centre.

sections.heading: What will I learn?
